title: Mean, Median, Mode Calculator
description: Calculate the mean (average), median (middle value), and mode (most frequent value) of any data set. Includes step-by-step solutions, frequency distribution, quartiles, variance, and standard deviation.

meta.title: Mean, Median, Mode Calculator - Free Statistics Calculator
meta.description: Free mean, median, mode calculator with step-by-step solutions. Calculate central tendency, quartiles, variance, and standard deviation.
meta.keywords: mean calculator, median calculator, mode calculator, average calculator, central tendency, statistics calculator, frequency distribution

inputs.dataInputPlaceholder:
Enter numbers separated by commas, spaces, or new lines
Example: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25
inputs.dataInputHelp: Enter numbers separated by commas, spaces, semicolons, or new lines. Supports both US (1,234.56) and European (1.234,56) number formats.
inputs.weightsInputPlaceholder: Enter weights in same order as data
inputs.weightsInputHelp: For weighted mean, enter weights corresponding to each data value.
inputs.arithmeticDescription: Sum of values divided by count
inputs.geometricDescription: Nth root of product of values
inputs.harmonicDescription: Count divided by sum of reciprocals
inputs.weightedDescription: Weighted sum divided by sum of weights

calc.cannotCalculateGeometric: Cannot calculate geometric mean (requires all positive values)
calc.cannotCalculateHarmonic: Cannot calculate harmonic mean (cannot include zero values)
calc.middleValueIs: The middle value is the median
calc.averageMiddleValues: Average of the two middle values
calc.countFrequencies: Count frequency of each unique value
calc.noModeAllEqual: All values appear equally often, so there is no mode
calc.noModeAllDifferent: All values are different, so there is no mode

disclaimer.text: This calculator provides statistical calculations for educational and informational purposes.
disclaimer.note: Results are rounded for display but calculations use full precision.

seo.whatIsTitle: What is a Mean, Median, Mode Calculator?
seo.whatIsContent: A mean, median, mode calculator is a statistical tool that helps you find the three main measures of central tendency in a data set. The mean (average) is the sum divided by the count, the median is the middle value when sorted, and the mode is the most frequently occurring value. These measures help summarize and understand data distributions, making them essential for statistics, data analysis, research, and everyday problem-solving.
seo.measuresIntro: Understanding when to use each measure is key to proper data analysis:
seo.measure1Desc: The arithmetic mean is calculated by adding all values and dividing by the count. It's sensitive to outliers but provides a good overall measure when data is normally distributed.
seo.measure2Desc: The median is the middle value when data is sorted. It's resistant to outliers and better represents typical values in skewed distributions.
seo.measure3Desc: The mode is the value that appears most often. Data can be unimodal (one mode), bimodal (two modes), multimodal, or have no mode if all values appear equally.
seo.whenToUseIntro: Choose the right measure of central tendency based on your data characteristics:
seo.useCase1: Use mean for normally distributed data without significant outliers
seo.useCase2: Use median when your data has outliers or is skewed (like income data)
seo.useCase3: Use mode for categorical data or to find the most common value
seo.useCase4: Use geometric mean for growth rates and multiplicative processes
seo.useCase5: Use harmonic mean for rates and ratios (like speeds)
seo.benefit1: All three measures at once - get mean, median, and mode in a single calculation
seo.benefit2: Multiple mean types - arithmetic, geometric, harmonic, and weighted means
seo.benefit3: Step-by-step solutions - understand exactly how each calculation is performed
seo.benefit4: Additional statistics - includes range, quartiles, variance, and standard deviation
seo.benefit5: Frequency distribution - see how often each value occurs in your data
seo.howToUseStep1: Enter your data values separated by commas, spaces, or new lines
seo.howToUseStep2: Select the type of mean you want to calculate (arithmetic is default)
seo.howToUseStep3: For weighted mean, enter corresponding weights
seo.howToUseStep5: View results including all central tendency measures and additional statistics
seo.tipsTitle: Tips for Working with Central Tendency
seo.tip1: Use median instead of mean when your data has significant outliers
seo.tip2: Mode is useful for categorical data and finding the most common value
seo.tip3: Geometric mean is best for growth rates and multiplicative processes
seo.tip4: Harmonic mean is appropriate for rates and ratios
seo.tip5: Consider all three measures together to understand your data distribution
seo.faq1Question: What is the difference between mean, median, and mode?
seo.faq1Answer: Mean is the average (sum divided by count), median is the middle value when sorted, and mode is the most frequent value. Each measure gives different insights: mean considers all values, median resists outliers, and mode shows the most common value.
seo.faq2Question: When should I use median instead of mean?
seo.faq2Answer: Use median when your data has outliers or is skewed. For example, income data often uses median because a few very high incomes can inflate the mean. The median better represents the typical value in such cases.
seo.faq3Question: Can there be more than one mode?
seo.faq3Answer: Yes. Data is unimodal with one mode, bimodal with two modes, or multimodal with more than two modes. If all values appear equally, there is no mode.
seo.faq4Answer: A weighted mean gives different importance to values based on their weights. It's used when some values matter more, like calculating course grades where different assignments have different point values.
seo.faq5Question: When should I use geometric mean?
seo.faq5Answer: Use geometric mean for multiplicative growth rates, like investment returns or population growth. It's appropriate when values are percentages or ratios that compound together.
seo.faq6Question: What is harmonic mean used for?
seo.faq6Answer: Harmonic mean is used for averaging rates. For example, if you drive 60 mph one way and 40 mph back, the harmonic mean gives the correct average speed (48 mph), not the arithmetic mean (50 mph).
seo.faq7Question: How do outliers affect mean, median, and mode?
seo.faq7Answer: Outliers significantly affect the mean by pulling it toward extreme values. Median is resistant to outliers since it only depends on the middle position. Mode is unaffected by outliers unless they become the most frequent value.
seo.faq8Question: What additional statistics does this calculator provide?
seo.faq8Answer: Beyond mean, median, and mode, this calculator provides: count, sum, range (max - min), quartiles (Q1, Q3), interquartile range (IQR), variance, standard deviation, and a complete frequency distribution table.
